Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..raw_text: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N.Y. 339 (1928)
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..proposition: 12. Defendant's negligent acts and omissions were the direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff's child's injuries, including a concussion and loss of consciousness, resulting in medical expenses of approximately $5,200 and lost wages of $1,500 for Plaintiff.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..case_name: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..support_reasoning: The proposition asserts that defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of a plaintiff child’s injuries and resulting economic losses. Palsgraf does not involve a child, medical expenses, or lost wages, and, more importantly, the Court holds there was no actionable negligence or duty owed to the plaintiff at all. Cardozo’s opinion rejects liability on duty/foreseeability grounds and expressly states that issues of proximate cause and damages are not reached, so it cannot be cited to support the proposition claimed.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..relevant_excerpt: "The conduct of the defendant’s guard, if a wrong in its relation to the holder of the package, was not a wrong in its relation to the plaintiff, standing far away. Relatively to her it was not negligence at all. Nothing in the situation gave notice that the falling package had in it the potency of peril to persons thus removed. Negligence is not actionable unless it involves the invasion of a legally protected interest, the violation of a right.… The law of causation, remote or proximate, is thus foreign to the case before us."

Altman v. Aronson, 231 N.E.2d 223 (Mass..proposition: 10. Defendant owed a duty of care to the children under its supervision at the community center, including Plaintiff's child, to provide adequate supervision and ensure their safety.

Darby v. Compagnie National Air France,.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns negligence, proximate causation of a child’s physical injuries (concussion, loss of consciousness), and resulting medical expenses and lost wages. The provided opinion is a Sixth Circuit standing decision in a Fair Housing Act and civil rights housing discrimination case; it does not involve negligence, physical injury, proximate cause, or damages of the type described. Therefore, this case cannot be authority for the stated negligence-causation proposition.
Darby v. Compagnie National Air France,.relevant_excerpt: The plaintiff in this housing discrimination action alleges that the racial steering practices of defendants, city of Cleveland Heights and non-profit neighborhood association, Heights Community Congress, violate both his statutory and constitutional rights under the Fair Housing Act, Title VIII of the Civil Rights Act of 1968, 42 U.S.C. Sec. 3604, the Thirteenth and Fourteenth Amendments, and Secs. 1981, 1982, 1983, 42 U.S.C.  The issue on appeal is whether plaintiff Smith…has standing to pursue the action.

Roberts v. Westerly, 632 N.E.2d 234 (Mas.support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt is a criminal appeal about a cocaine delivery conviction and deals with hearsay, co-conspirator statements, ineffective assistance, prosecutorial remarks, and sentencing. It does not involve a community center, supervision of children, or any discussion of a duty of care toward children under supervision. Therefore, it provides no authority for the asserted negligence-duty proposition.
Roberts v. Westerly, 632 N.E.2d 234 (Mas.relevant_excerpt:
For all of the foregoing reasons, we find that the out-of-court statements made by the co-conspirators, Bo Collins and Lattimore, sufficiently established a prima facie case of a conspiracy between themselves and defendant.

Finally, defendant contends that his sentence of 30 years is unfairly disparate with Albert Lattimore’s sentence of 18 years for the same crime... Under these facts we cannot say the trial court’s sentence was an abuse of discretion.

Kent v. Sports World, Inc., 100 F.3d 148.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a §1983 due process/liberty interest claim arising from stigmatizing statements made about a college basketball coach in connection with his termination. It does not address premises liability, negligence, duty of care, supervision of children, or hazardous activities. The discussion of ‘kids’ and ‘young men entrusted to his care and supervision’ is in the context of reputational stigma, not a tort duty to supervise or breach thereof, so it does not support the stated negligence proposition.
Kent v. Sports World, Inc., 100 F.3d 148.relevant_excerpt: “In other words, Campanelli has a reasonable chance of proving that he has been charged with immoral conduct within the meaning of Roth by abusing the young men entrusted to his care and supervision.”

Sheehan v. O\u2019Connor, 537 N.E.2d 605.case_name: Congregation Beth Sholom & Community Center, Inc. v. Building Commissioner
Sheehan v. O\u2019Connor, 537 N.E.2d 605.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns interpretation of a Massachusetts statute requiring automatic sprinklers after “major alterations” to a building. It deals with statutory construction, the definition of “major alterations,” and vagueness/due process concerns. It does not involve negligence, duty of care, supervision of children, or any factual context about unsafe activities or hazardous conduct, so it cannot support the stated proposition about breach of a duty of care through inadequate supervision.
Sheehan v. O\u2019Connor, 537 N.E.2d 605.relevant_excerpt: "The plaintiff, Congregation Beth Sholom & Community Center, Inc., filed a complaint in the Superior Court against various officials of the town of Framingham, raising the issue whether work it did in a building it owns and occupies constituted 'major alterations' and whether, as a consequence, it is required by the terms of G. L. c. 148, § 26G, to install an adequate system of automatic sprinklers in the building."
